title: Monday evening news briefing: Boost for election hopes even as MPs expected to reject motion
text:

Boost to election hopes despite MPs' plan to reject vote tonight

This evening, MPs will vote on the Government's general election motion, which is not expected to pass. Yet the chances of the Prime Minister securing the election he desires have undoubtedly been boosted. If the motion fails, Boris Johnson will introduce an election bill "almost identical" to that put forward by the Lib Dems and SNP, that would only need a majority, rather than the two-thirds needed under the Fixed Term Parliaments Act. The Lib Dems indicated they will back the Government's one-line Bill this evening, providing it includes a "triple lock" guarantee that a no-deal Brexit cannot happen. Tony Diver has written this handy guide to tonight's vote and what may happen afterwards. As ever, you can follow the developments on The Telegraph's politics liveblog.

This comes after the European Union agreed a three-month "flextension" to the October 31 Brexit deadline. Emmanuel Macron had blocked an EU decision on it on Friday because he opposed a longer delay but EU27 ambassadors approved an extension to January 31, 2020, in a 20-minute meeting in Brussels this morning. There is an option of leaving earlier if the Brexit deal is ratified in the House of Commons and European Parliament. To compound an already bruising day for those in favour of remaining in the EU, the People's Vote campaign has been plunged into chaos by the sacking of two senior figures.
